com.ibm.tspaces
Class SuperTuple

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--com.ibm.tspaces.SuperTuple
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Cloneable, java.io.Serializable
Direct Known Subclasses:
SubclassableTuple, Tuple
public abstract class SuperTuple
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable

A SuperTuple is an ordered sequence of Fields. Since it's abstract, any SuperTuple is actually either a Tuple or a SubclassableTuple.

Refer to the SuperTuple.matches() method for the matching algorithm for Tuples

Template Tuples:
Normally Tuples contain "Actual Fields that contain data and these Tuples are written to and taken from TupleSpaces.

But we also have Template Tuples that are used for matching Tuples to be retrieved. These Template Tuples have zero or more "Formal" Fields that contains only the class of the value that is to be matched. 

 For Example:
    Tuple template = new Tuple("Key1",new Field(String.class));
The above would match any Tuple that contained "Key1" in the 1st Field and any String value in the 2nd and final Field.

We have defined a "Null Tuple" as a wildcard that matches all Tuples. A "Null Tuple" is a SuperTuple with no fields, not a null reference to a SuperTuple.
For Example: Tuple nullTuple = new Tuple();
Since Formal Fields match the class and any subclass, new Field(Serializable.class) can act as a wildcard for any one of the fields.

Another Example: 

       TupleSpace ts = new TupleSpace("test");
       Tuple tuple = new Tuple("Key1","Data1");
       ts.write(tuple);
  
       Tuple template = new Tuple("Key1",new Field(String.class));
       Tuple result = ts.take(template);
       String data = rusult.getField(1).getValue();

Author:
Daniel Ford, Tobin Lehman, Stephen McLaughry, Peter Wyckoff, Ben Y. Zhao
See Also:
Tuple, SubclassableTuple, Field, TupleSpace, Serialized Form

Constructor Detail

SuperTuple

public SuperTuple()
The default SuperTuple constructor. Constructs a NULL SuperTuple, one with no Fields. Subsequent Fields can be added with the "add" method.
See Also:
add(com.ibm.tspaces.Field)

SuperTuple

public SuperTuple(java.io.Serializable obj)
           throws TupleSpaceException
Make a Tuple whose Field is the type and value of an Object. If the object itself is a Field, then it will be used as the Field and not as the Field's value.
Parameters:
obj - the value of the first Field of the Tuple.

add

public void add(Field f_)
Add a Field to the SuperTuple. It is added to the "end" of the collection of the other Fields. If the Field is an instance of XMLField, then the Tuple is marked as having an XMLField.
Parameters:
f_ - The Field to be added to the SuperTuple.

getTimeStamp

public long getTimeStamp()
Get the timeStamp of when the Tuple was written into the TupleSpace on the server. Only Tuples that are returned from the server will contain a Timestamp.
Returns:
long timeStamp

setTimeStamp

public void setTimeStamp(long time)
Set the TimeStamp value. Should only be called by TSDB on an insert. If the client sets this field the results are unpredictable.
Parameters:
time - The current time (from new Date.getTime();)

getExpire

public long getExpire()
Get the Expire time interval (ms) of the Tuple
Returns:
long Expire

setExpire

public void setExpire(long time)
Set the _expire value. Normally the client would set this value if it is desired to expire this Tuple at some point. The default is for _expire to be set to 0 and never expire the Tuple
Parameters:
time - The current time (from new Date.getTime();)

isExpired

public boolean isExpired()
Return true if the current time is greater than the Tuple (_timeStamp + _expire) Normally this should only be done by the server since the _timestamp is set by the server and the client and server clocks may not be in sync.
Returns:
true if currentTime > (_timeStamp + _expire)

matches

public boolean matches(SuperTuple t_)
Return true if the specified Tuple matches this Tuple. It is important to note that when matching a template tuple against the tuples in a TupleSpace, the current Tuple must be the template tuple. I.e. t1.matches(t2); t1 must be the template tuple. 
 The match criteria is:
 
 If this class is not an instance of the target class 
   return false
 
 We have defined a template Tuple with no fields as a wildcard that 
 matches everything.  Tuple t0 = new Tuple();
 If this tuple has 0 fields 
   return true

 If the number of fields do not match
   return false

 if the Field.matches() method for each field returns true 
   return true

 else 
    return false
Parameters:
t_ - The SuperTuple to compare.
Returns:
true if the SuperTuples are equal, false otherwise.
See Also:
Field

equals

public boolean equals(java.lang.Object t_)
Return true if the specified Tuple is equal to this Tuple. This is different than matches because we don't support a wildcard tuple.
Overrides:
equals in class java.lang.Object
Parameters:
t_ - The SuperTuple to compare.
Returns:
true if the Tuples are equal, false otherwise.
See Also:
Object.equals(java.lang.Object)

template

public boolean template()
Deprecated. Since we no longer differentiate between "formal" and "actual" tuples, this is no longer useful.

Return true if the Tuple is a template. A Tuple is a template if it has at least one formal Field.
Returns:
true if the Tuple has at least one formal Field

name - The name of the Field to look for.

true if the Tuple has a Field with the passed name.

clone

public java.lang.Object clone()
                       throws java.lang.CloneNotSupportedException
Return a clone of the this SuperTuple. This will first check for a SuperTuple that contains Fields with only "simple" cloneable objects and will clone it by simply calling the clone methods for the fields.

If the SuperTuple contains objects that are not: String or extends Number or Boolean then convert SuperTuple to a byte array that contains the serialized version of the object then convert it back to a SuperTuple. This is the equivalent of a deep copy

Overrides:
clone in class java.lang.Object
Returns:
clone of the SuperTuple Object.

setFields

protected void setFields(java.util.Vector fields)
Reset the Vector that contains the Fields Used to clone the SuperTuple Since clients should not be aware of this Vector this must be a protected field.
Parameters:
fields - Vector that holds the Fields
